div.head: The Å¿econd Å¿ort of PapiÅ¿ticall Miracles, comprehendeth counterfeit or humane Å¿ignes which were Å¿eene to happen, but were not true Miracles, though they Å¿eemed to be Å¿uch to the Å¿pectators.
div.p:
SVch are the Miracles recited euer-and-anone in the PapiÅ¿ticall Legends concerning Images that Å¿weate bloud, whoÅ¿e haire and nailes grow, the which almoÅ¿t all the common people, and many others of better ranke, beleeue really to happen in Å¿ome of our SpaniÅ¿h Images: but
the truth is, that Fryars to attract the people and the almes of Å¿uch as giue credit to them, to their MonaÅ¿teries, doe faÅ¿ten counterfeit haire to Å¿ome Images of ChriÅ¿t crucified, and apply falÅ¿e nayles alÅ¿o, the which Å¿ometimes they take away by night, placing in their roome others differing from them; and by Å¿uch Å¿light (for herein they are dextrious Artifts) they perÅ¿wade the ignorant and Å¿imple people, that the haires and nayles doe truely grow, and with Å¿emblable iuglings they counterfeit the Å¿weating of Images: but let vs heare a learned perÅ¿on of Spaine what hee Å¿aith, and thinketh of Å¿uch Miracles and the actors of them; You muÅ¿t not credit, Å¿aith he,Mateo Aleman en la hiÅ¿toria de Å¿an Antoniode Padua pag. 107.
what ignorant and vnconÅ¿cionable men affirme, Å¿aying, there are Images that Å¿weat bloud, whoÅ¿e haires waxe, and nailes are cut, it is an vntruth, a meere inuention and knauery: hee addeth, an Image of wood, or other mettall, cannot euacuate Å¿weat, neither doth it's haire grow, for it is counterfeit, nor conÅ¿equently the nayles which are carued by the hands of a wretched man, and in liueleÅ¿Å¿e wood: The nailes (obÅ¿erue this) which truely grow, are the infernall auarice of thoÅ¿e who inuent them for their abhominable ends: theÅ¿e and Å¿uch like Å¿tratagems, acquire to the Fryars immunerable riches, to which no Indies but thoÅ¿e of Purgatory, which are the non vltra, are comparable. There are Images which maintaine very opulently a great multitude of Fryars; becauÅ¿e vpon the bruite of Miracles, infinite people reÅ¿ort to them with money in their hands, for the Å¿ight of Å¿uch Imager is prohibited to Å¿uch as buy it not: Of which number is our Lady of Atocha, of MonÅ¿arrate, of Puy, the holy Crucifixe of Burgos; All theÅ¿e are
houÅ¿es which from a mean beginning are by reaÅ¿on of the Images grown to Å¿o an incredible greatneÅ¿Å¿e, that now they are the richeÅ¿t and moÅ¿t Å¿plended in all Europe. That of BurgeÅ¿Å¿e is of my Order of the AuguÅ¿tines, of which I can report as an eye-witneÅ¿Å¿e, that it may enter into competicion for riches with a City. When I was there, I diligently laboured to Å¿ee Å¿ome Miracle of thoÅ¿e infinite ones which the Fryars diuulged daily of that Image, but I could neuer Å¿ee any, and it happened alike to many of my Companions, and therefore one of them was wont to Å¿ay, that the Miracles of that Image were as thefts, which for the moÅ¿t part are done by night in the darke.

To the Å¿econd Å¿ort of Miracles,Salazar en la hiÅ¿to. de la prouincia de CaÅ¿tilla de Å¿an FranciÅ¿co, pag. 44. appertaineth that which Å¿ome others relate of a certaine religious woman, which in Bolonia was held for a Saint, and Å¿hewed the wounds of the holy paÅ¿Å¿ion of our Sauiour in her feete, hands, and Å¿ide, and many times the bloud diÅ¿tilled from her head, as if it had beene pierced with a crowne of thornes; and in fine, it was all found to be impoÅ¿ture and couÅ¿enage: Of this I could alleadge many HiÅ¿tories, as this Author acknowledgeth, but for auoiding prolixitie I omit them, contenting my Å¿elfe with one moÅ¿t true preÅ¿ident, which not many yeares Å¿ince happened in Spaine. There was in Valladolid, a famous City of Spaine, a IeÅ¿uite, who was Å¿o in loue with a noble Widdow which was wont to confeÅ¿Å¿e vnto him, that perceiuing by her confeÅ¿Å¿ion, that Å¿hee was an impregnable caÅ¿tle, as being moÅ¿t chaÅ¿te, and fearing God, reÅ¿olued to conquer her by an extraordinary and miraculous way, to which intent, he Å¿uborned with many gifts, one of the Å¿aid Ladies
Gentlewomen, that with all Å¿ecrecy, Å¿hee Å¿hould put vpon, or neere the BoulÅ¿ter of the Bed where Å¿hee Å¿lept, a little Å¿chedule, the which Å¿he accordingly performed, and her MiÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e going to bed, found it, and much meruailing at it, called her Seruant, and asked her if Å¿hee had laid the Å¿chedule there; Å¿hee anÅ¿wered no, aÅ¿Å¿euering it with a thouÅ¿and oathes and proteÅ¿tations; this (and becauÅ¿e her Lady reputed her for an honeÅ¿t vertuous maide) cauÅ¿ed her to thinke that Å¿hee knew nothing of the writing, & becauÅ¿e there was no body elÅ¿e in the houÅ¿e, Å¿he was perÅ¿waded that it was Å¿ent from heauen: Å¿he remaining alone in her lodging, hauing firÅ¿t charged the DamoÅ¿ell touching this Å¿ecret, and reading the Å¿chedule, found the contents of it as followeth: MoÅ¿t deare Daughter, I haue elected you, that in this deplorable time, you Å¿hould be the Mother of a Sonne, that Å¿hall reforme the world, and this muÅ¿t happen by the co-operation of a man, chooÅ¿e whom you will, but marry not, for my will is that thou remaine a widdow. If the reading of this Å¿chedule bred admiration in her, it is needeleÅ¿Å¿e to coniecture, it is Å¿ufficient to tell you, that preÅ¿ently after breake of day, Å¿hee went to Å¿eeke her ConfeÅ¿Å¿or, to whom Å¿he declared Å¿ub Å¿igillo confeÅ¿Å¿ionis, what had befallen her the former night, and intreated him to counÅ¿ell her what he thought beÅ¿t; hee perÅ¿waded her after large conferences, (note the great Å¿ubtilty of the IeÅ¿uite) Å¿he Å¿hould not lightly beleeue it, becauÅ¿e Sathan is wont to transfigure himÅ¿elfe into an Angell of light, to delude the better Å¿ort, and that Å¿he Å¿hould recommend that buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e heartily to our Lady, and that hee would alÅ¿o doe it, that Å¿hee might inÅ¿pire what Å¿hould be beÅ¿t: and thus the Lady
returned to her houÅ¿e, and Å¿pent the greateÅ¿t part of the day in recommending vnto God the good Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e of it, and when night approached, Å¿he entred into her chamber to lye downe, where Å¿hee found a Å¿econd Å¿cedule to the Å¿ame purpoÅ¿e; preÅ¿ently the next morning Å¿he returned vnto her ConfeÅ¿Å¿or, who perÅ¿waded her to tarry yet another night, and if Å¿he found a third, then Å¿he might hold it as a thing ordained by heauen, and Å¿hould diÅ¿poÅ¿e her Å¿elfe to the accompliÅ¿hment of it; Å¿he found one the next night conueied thither by the meanes aboue Å¿pecified, and communicating it vnto the IeÅ¿uite, both of them determined, with his no Å¿mall delight to beginne the execution of that which was contained in the Å¿chedule, which was ennacted the Å¿ame day in the houÅ¿e of the Å¿aid Lady, and continued Å¿ome dayes, with the great Å¿hame and diÅ¿grace of the Lady, and with Å¿uch impudency and perpetude of the IeÅ¿uite, that Å¿he thought it paÅ¿t the bounds, not onely of a deuout and Å¿pirituall man, but of the moÅ¿t carnall and brutiÅ¿h one in the world, Å¿he began to Å¿uÅ¿pect that this Companion had beene the Author of the Miracle, which Å¿urmize increaÅ¿ed, becauÅ¿e after Å¿he had told him that Å¿he was with childe, and that therefore no further action was needfull, in as much as when the end aimed at is attained vnto, the media conducing thereunto ceaÅ¿e; he notwithÅ¿tanding ceaÅ¿ed not to importune her, and alÅ¿o to force her with Å¿mal modeÅ¿ty to doe that which Å¿he would haue excuÅ¿ed: TheÅ¿e and other conÅ¿iderations, moued her to tell the IeÅ¿uite, that becauÅ¿e her neighbours began to murmure and iudge ill of his frequent viÅ¿iting her, it was meete hee Å¿hould totally
forbeare her company; of neceÅ¿Å¿ity hee was faine to yeeld though vnwillingly: When her time of childe-bearing was come, Å¿he had a faire Daughter, and Å¿o perceiued that the IeÅ¿uite had beguiled her, Å¿hee acquainted her kindred with the buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e, who notwithÅ¿tanding all the diligence they vÅ¿ed, could not deterre the malifactor who was fled away.
There is no other which I know hath written this HiÅ¿tory, but the common fame of it in Spaine implyes the truth of it.

div.head: To the laÅ¿t kinde appertaine Diabolicall Miracles, which were onely iugling trickes, or did really happen: to this we referre caÅ¿ting out of Diuels, healing of the Å¿icke, giuing Å¿ight to the blinde, &c.
div.p:
THat which Father Ojea Å¿aith of the Miracles of VeÅ¿patian, Ojea en la vida de ChriÅ¿to pag. 154. who reÅ¿tored Å¿ight vnto a blinde man, and healed a lame man, his words are: The diuell could mingle with the Å¿pittle of VeÅ¿patian, Å¿ome powders of particular vertue which might forthwith take away the clowdes, and diÅ¿perÅ¿e the other obÅ¿ticles which were in the eyes of the blinde man, that he might recouer his Å¿ight; and when hee touched with his foote the other which was lame, hee might apply another remedy of thoÅ¿e many which are extant in nature, which he knoweth well
through his long experience, and Å¿o hee might bee healed. We iudge the Å¿ame of PapiÅ¿ticall Miracles: It cannot be denied but diuers meruailous effects haue bin produced among them, but either by deceit or art of the diuell, Å¿omtimes the Fryars themÅ¿elues not knowing it, & Å¿omtimes holding correÅ¿pondency with the diuell: That this is Å¿o, the reaÅ¿ons following conclude, I. BecauÅ¿e PapiÅ¿ticall Miracles are to corroborate Å¿uperÅ¿tition & falÅ¿e Doctrine, & therefore cannot be eÅ¿Å¿entially diuine; but that they confirme falÅ¿e doctrine, I proue by this inÅ¿uing example;Lib. 4. pag 56. del prado eÅ¿piritual. the firÅ¿t wherof is of an Abbot which abÅ¿olued a Fryar after he was dead, and impoÅ¿ed a puniÅ¿hment vpon him that he Å¿hould be in Purgatory vntil his body were buried, as Å¿oon as the deceaÅ¿ed heard this, he gaue a great & fearfull Å¿houte, which was heard all ouer the MoneÅ¿tary, Å¿aying, Oh mercileÅ¿Å¿e Father, why haue you inioyned me to abide Å¿o long in Purgatory? This example containeth, firÅ¿t, three, and thoÅ¿e no Å¿mall errors of the RomiÅ¿h Church; to wit, the doctrine of Purgatory, that of humane Å¿atisfaction, and the neceÅ¿Å¿ity of auricular confeÅ¿Å¿ion, and infoldeth alÅ¿o another error not onely repugnant to truth, but alÅ¿o contrary to that which the very Church of Rome it Å¿elfer beleeues; to wit, that a man may be abÅ¿olued from his Å¿innes after he is dead: And here I would intreate the firÅ¿t Monke that readeth this, to tell mee where that Fryar which departed was, vntill his Abbot came to giue him abÅ¿olution; for I cannot conceiue where he might Å¿oiourne during that intervall; for in Purgatory hee could not be, whether (if we giue credence vnto PapiÅ¿ts) none entreth vntill hee hath receiued
abÅ¿olution of his Å¿innes, neither by the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on could he be in heauen, becauÅ¿e the PapiÅ¿ts doe not Å¿end the Å¿oules that haue beene in heauen vnto Purgatory; but contrarily,Nunnes can neuer come out of the MoneÅ¿tary. they Å¿end thoÅ¿e that are in Purgatory vnto heauen. As little could it be in hell; becauÅ¿e as Å¿choole-boyes know, there is no redemption; & therfore the PrieÅ¿ts Å¿aith not, deliuer vs Lord, ab infero, from hel, but, a porta inferi, from hel gate, and if once thou entreÅ¿t there, thou maieÅ¿t make ful account to be a Nunne of hel: wel, if this Fryar was neither in heauen, Purgatory, nor in Hell, where was he? alas I had forgot Limbus, but it is all one, for what had Limbus (a place deÅ¿tinate to Innocents) to doe with this nocent Fryar, which forgaue not his owne Abbot, euen then when hee dealt Å¿o compaÅ¿Å¿ionately with him? The Å¿econd example is of a Gentleman, who hauing vowed to turne Monke, was condemned for not being compleat in his vow, (though at the houre of his death,Jbid pag. 45. he vÅ¿ed all the diligence which a good & faithful ChriÅ¿tian might vÅ¿e for acquitting of his conÅ¿cience: After his deceaÅ¿e hee appeared vnto an Abbot, which asked him; What doth the bleÅ¿Å¿ed Saint Vincent for thee, perchance he doth not aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t thee in this thy neceÅ¿Å¿ity, Å¿eeing thou haÅ¿t giuen Å¿o much money to his AdminiÅ¿trators, that they might labour in building of his MoneÅ¿tary; to whom the Gentleman anÅ¿wered, I reÅ¿orted to him, but he hath made me wait many dayes to talk with him, & when I could not doe it after many tedious attendances, I now deÅ¿paire of euer talking with him, or hauing his fauour; it were friuolous to employ any arguments to perÅ¿wade the learned, or thoÅ¿e which are not altogether ignorant and blinde,
that this is one of the moÅ¿t vaine MonaÅ¿ticall fables, or ridiculous eluÅ¿ions of Sathan; I Å¿ay, for Å¿atisfaction of the ignorant, that this example hath for end and Å¿cope, the authorizing of one of the moÅ¿t pernitious errors of the Church of Rome, (viz) that the vow of leading a MonaÅ¿ticall life, is not onely lawfull, but alÅ¿o that hee which performeth it not, can by no meanes be Å¿aued, how Å¿olicitous Å¿oeuer hee be for clearing of his conÅ¿cience. I would haue the PapiÅ¿ts tell me, if thoÅ¿e dayes, which were not a few if we beleeue the PapiÅ¿ts, that Saint Vincent cauÅ¿ed this poore Gentleman to dance attendance, preceded his condemnation yea or no; for if they did precede, then is it indubitorily falÅ¿e, that euery one heareth at his death the Å¿entence of his condemnation or Å¿aluation, which I preÅ¿ume no papiÅ¿t in the world is Å¿o impudent as to affirme: if they were Å¿ubÅ¿equent vnto his condemnation, it followes that thoÅ¿e which are condemned in hell, come forth to Å¿olicite the Saints of heauen to infranchize them from thence, and haue hope of their enlargement, & that God wil revoke the Å¿entence he pronounced againÅ¿t them; for no man Å¿oliciteth a buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e, knowing it impoÅ¿Å¿ible to compaÅ¿Å¿e his intent, all which how erronious, abÅ¿urd, and ridiculous it is let the Pontificies themÅ¿elues iudge.

In the laÅ¿t place I ranke the reuelations made vnto many hee and Å¿hee PapiÅ¿ticall Saints,SoÅ¿a en al tratado de la concepcion Pag. 86. eÅ¿pecially to Saint Bridget, to confirme the conception of the holy Virgin to haue beene without originall Å¿inne, which haue beene examined and allowed of as diuine ones, by many Cardinals and Prelates; yea, euen by the very Popes themÅ¿elues; whether theÅ¿e reuelations be
reluctous vnto holy Scripture yea or no, I appeale to the iudgement of the famous and celebrious Order of Preaching Fryars, Å¿o called by way of eminency; the which with many others that Å¿impathize with them herein, haue euidenced in their writings and Pulpits with luculent authoritie Å¿cited out of holy Writ and auncient Doctors, and with euident arguments, that the holy Virgin was conceiued in Å¿inne; and the authority of this graue order of Dominicans is of Å¿uch force, that although the Pope complying with the FranciÅ¿can and IeÅ¿uiticall Orders, great Antagonis to the former, doth ratifie the Å¿aid reuelations, yet dares he not define this queÅ¿tion of the conception againÅ¿t them, though it be true, that according to the tenent of PapiÅ¿ticall doctrine, he being in conÅ¿cience obliged to doe it, as many Pontificiall Doctors doe clearely demonÅ¿trate, and amongÅ¿t them moÅ¿t elegantly, that renowned SoÅ¿a, BiÅ¿hop of Segouia: Vbi Å¿up. I will tranÅ¿itorily Å¿ay, that Cardinall Caietane, a conÅ¿picuous Author, as all know, doth many Authors affirme, that Saint Catelyn haue a reuelation contradictory to that of Saint Bridget, which the FranciÅ¿cans and IeÅ¿uites Å¿ay; hee inuented of his owne head, to ratifye his opinion, whence appeareth, how the Fryars deride one another concerning the reuelations.

The Å¿econd reaÅ¿on prouing the PapiÅ¿ticall Miracles to be diabolicall, is, becauÅ¿e the actions which they vÅ¿ually alleadge for Miracles, are often times Å¿o childiÅ¿h and ridiculous, that euery one may with facility perceiue that they proceede not from the holy GhoÅ¿t;Enel prado, eÅ¿piritual pag. 100. Å¿uch was that Miracle of the Crow, which for hauing Å¿tollen a Ring, as they Å¿ay, did incurre Å¿entence of
excommunication, and began forthwith to pine away by little and little, refuÅ¿ing to eate, or crake, nor to continue the other paÅ¿times and demonÅ¿trations of iockondneÅ¿Å¿e, which irrationall creatures are accuÅ¿tomed to doe, vntill an Abbot had abÅ¿olued it, from which moment the Crow began to bee iouiall, returning vnto it's former habit.Ibid pag 24. Semblable vnto this Miracle, is that of a little Bitch, which dyed becauÅ¿e it entred into the holy Cell of Saint Gregory; Ibid pag. 103. of like quality is that of Saint Bernard, of whom it goes for current, that he excommunicated a great number of Flyes, which dyed, being Å¿trucken with the arrow of excommunication: but aboue all theÅ¿e Miracles, that of a Fryar is remarkeable,Ibid. pag 47. who kept the Swine of his combent, and on a day aÅ¿Å¿embling them into one place, made vnto them this, no leÅ¿Å¿e graue then eloquent oration: you know brothers, Å¿wine, how in the time that I haue Å¿o carefully kept you, I haue Å¿ufficiently taught and inÅ¿tructed you, where you may, and where you may not feede; therefore I requeÅ¿t you, that you roue not out of your bounds, for feare of cauÅ¿ing iarres in the MonaÅ¿tery, through the detriment of their neighbours; and in confidence that Å¿o you will doe, I will repaire to the Conuent, promiÅ¿ing you Å¿oone to returne: and Å¿o he went, and all the Å¿wine as if they had the vÅ¿e of reaÅ¿on, kept themÅ¿elues in the hils apertayning to the Fryars, inÅ¿omuch that Å¿ome labouring men which deÅ¿ired to catch them, could by no meanes driue them thence, notwithÅ¿tanding they gaue them many a blow with cudgels; who is there of Å¿ound iudgement, that doth thinke God is the Author of Å¿uch fopperyes? It is the
property of the diuell, and not of God, to delude men with Å¿uch.

I will put a period vnto this diÅ¿courÅ¿e, with one very true and domeÅ¿ticall example, that all the world may plainely diÅ¿cry the falÅ¿ity of PapiÅ¿ticall Miracles, and Å¿o abhorre them.
